title: Are Asians smarter than other people? - Quora

response.answer_text: In general, I've met a lot of average and not very intelligent asian people, but few really brilliant people. Are we talking about Asian Americans?  If yes, then chances are, these people were pushed to be driven and successful starting at a very young age.  This is likely because the parents who immigrated to America are all the high achievers who dreamed of a better future of opportunity for their kids.  They all had to work their asses off to get overseas.  Having high achievers raise kids to be high achievers starts a trend.  This developed sense of expectation leads to either high numbers (GPAs, test scores), or ambition in other forms.  This probably creates the illusion that 'asians are smarter" but it is really a cultural difference in how we define our standards and what influenced those standards in the first place. In reality, I see them as any other people. Go to somewhere in Asia and you'll see your mix of intelligent and unintelligent people like you would anywhere else.  There are certain areas where there is a more highly concentrated population of high achieving asians, and it is possible that asians steal the spotlight because they are technically a 'minority' that competes with caucasians for jobs, status, and etc. We can go into theories of intelligence but that is another topic.  Point is, there are more hard working asian people who were influenced by others (most likely their parents), and thus they are seen as perhaps 'smarter.'  Culture really goes a long way.  For example, Koreans are really good at Starcraft because there is a culture over there revolving around it; it is a national sport.  Japanese are known for their anime/video game/tech accomplishments because there is a culture that generates a lot of passion and emphasis on those areas.    Likewise, Asian Americans who are successful overseas are where they are because they were raised on a culture revolving around hard work and success.  For the same reasons, other races are known to excel or be absorbed in other pursuits. I am kind of generalizing but so is this question.

when you answer a question about intelligence with race, you are entering the land of eugenics and racism. you don't want to go there. it's where the Nazis live. a more interesting question, to me, is: are there styles of parenting and cultural values that increase academic achievment?. the answer seems to be yes. my family history in education went thus: great grand: 3rd grade. grandparents generation: some high school, one went to a prestigious boys science high school, equal to an associated degree; parents: masters degree and PhD. (me slacker with BA). very typical in that group, which happened to be Eastern European. husband's family: great grands: literate: grands: business owners with high school and some college or night school. husband's generation: BA to PhD. happens to be Jews. my observation is that parents parent differently. some parents believe putting kids under pressure to succeed strengthens them and is the right thing to do. other cultures feel like too much pressure is a bad thing. atm, many Asian kids seem to be parented in such a way thato an outside success is very important. But it's a stereotype, and I can also think of an Asian family I know that does not pressure their kids, because they say the pressure almost killed them. who knows what is right for someone's family? you can look at statistics and see that Asian kids are doing well. but I'd like to hear some Asian voices on this. My son's used to say that “B" is a Jewish “F" (failing grade), but they said it jokingly. if they had worked hard, we didnt care about a B. Again, you cant tie success to ethnicity, because it leads to tying failure to ethnicity, and that is the road to hell.

I’d like to say we aren’t. To determine whether someone is “smart” you have to define “smart”. Does “smart” mean being able to come up with logical solutions quickly? Does “smart” mean being able to talk and convince people? Does “smart” mean being able to play an instrument well, paint well, play a sport well? I feel that there is some innate Asian culture at work here. The pressure to be number one. That if you are not number one, you are worthless. That education is the key to success. There is a reason why the suicide rate in Japan, Korea, and China are so high, especially the famous Japanese September 1 suicides, the sudden spike of suicide on the first day of school. Students are pressured, the ones that cannot keep up are left behind. There is no second of your day that is not studying, studying, studying. And it’s not only studying. Parents pressure their children into playing instruments, sports, etc. And that sense of “I am garbage if I’m not number one” also plays into hobbies such as gaming and other activities. So a desperation to be the best, borderline-abusive parents, and a cutthroat environment all bring Asians into success. That’s my take on the topic based on research and personal experience.

There are many different types of “smart”/intelligence and having good grades definitely does NOT cover all of them. So as an Asian, the answer to your question is definitely no. Any Asian that says yes is racist (as it's apparent they think they're the smartest race and above everyone else) and ignorant about the many difference types of intelligence out there. In 1983 an American developmental psychologist Howard Gardener described 9 types of intelligence Naturalist (nature smart)Musical (sound smart)Logical-mathematical (number/reasoning smart)Existential (life smart)Interpersonal (people smart)Bodily-kinesthetic (body smart)Linguistic (word smart)Intra-personal (self smart)Spatial (picture smart)If you want to be stereotypical, Asians are bad drivers. This means they possess little to no spatial and bodily-kinesthetic intelligence at all.

The quoted claims contradict what we know from current, peer-reviewed psychological research in many ways. Here are two important ones: - Measured intelligence (via IQ tests, and assuming that these are valid to begin with) has increased continuously in many countries of the world over the past half century (see Flynn effect). If intelligence were determined entirely by genetics, measured intelligence should remain stable. This makes it clear that there is a significant social or environmental component to measured intelligence. - The correlation between brain size and intelligence is only .35. Brain size alone does not determine intelligence: Hunt, Earl; Carlson, Jerry (2007). "Considerations relating to the study of group differences in intelligence". Perspectives on Psychological Science 2 (2): 194–213. It bears pointing out how difficult it is to make inferences based on ethnicity given that genetics and culture are often confounded. Moreover, diet is also intertwined with culture, and recent research has shown that the things we eat can change how our brains work. For example, eating yogurt affects your brain function (Changing gut bacteria through diet affects brain function, UCLA study shows). Given that eating yogurt can impact cognitive function, it's doubtful that something as complex as intelligence is solely determined by genetics.

I am not an expert but I don´t usually see people pointing the fact that Asians, at least as I see, are usually less emotional than typical western people. I´ve never been to any Asian country but I do live in the city with the biggest amount of Japanese outside of Japan, São Paulo. We have a large chinese community here too. What I have observed is Asians are significantly less influenced by the full range of emotions white or black people are subject to. If this is good or bad, of if this is a case of repressed emotions due to cultural factors or simply genetic, it´s difficult to know. But when they are perfoming intellectual activities, it seems clear to me that emotions play a smaller role, and therefore they are better able to focus and perceive their own thinking processes, which ends up making a great difference in the long run. We must also bear in mind that although social pressure exists in every culture, in the western world (which could include Latam for this purpose) most people won´t feel rejected by their parents or have their honor damaged if they fail to join university or get a good position in a company. Asia has changed a lot but honor is still a critical thing in their culture, to the point some guys even end up seeing suicide as an option depending on the damage done to their reputation, which in turn largely dependent on their intellectual capabilities.

Asians are the largest group of people on the planet, with just two nationalities, Indian and Chinese, making up over 1/3 of the human race. I haven't googled it, but including all other Asians to that figure should easily make over half the world population. With that many people it shouldn't be a surprise that many of the worlds "smart" people are Asian. It's simple numbers. "Asians" probably also have the largest share of "non-smart" people as well. Now if we ignore that question and you're asking about why Asian immigrants seem to be disproportionately successful, it comes down to biased immigration systems that favor lawyers, doctors, college educated etc immigrants over others. Asian immigrants tend to come from families that are disproportionately educated and successful compared to the average person in the immigrants own home country.  If the U.S. For example didn't have an immigration bias and gave equal access to all Asian immigrants regardless of education level, you'd most likely see a vastly different Asian American demographic that may not be as economically successful.

Being raised in a Korean household, I am pushed to excel from a young age . For example, by Grade 3 I knew 9 times tables. My dad is very strict about math, especially marks and grades. In my school, a lot of people always say that I am smart, even though I don’t think so myself. Being an asian, as you would assume, I have met a lot other asians both Korean and that of other asian countries. I wouldn’t say that all asians are smarter than other people, but there are certainly brilliant ones I’ve met myself.

Well, "Asians" constitutes rather a large and heterogeneous category.  National assessments are controversial, and not purely for reasons of methodology.  But Hong Kong does have the highest IQ on the planet, and I suppose it is more Chinese than European. Note that to recognize the inherent diversity of life is to be open to the fact that the nature of the kinds of talents found in different nations is that they are not all the same.  So in recognizing that Chinese tend to have a higher overall IQ than others means also to recognize that this is not uniform across all sub-scores: I think it is more pronounced in non-verbal than verbal intelligence.  There are many very talented Chinese lawyers in the world.  But I do not think it is a coincidence that the representation of this group in different fields is different from what would be expected based on factors beyond who their grandparents were... National IQ Means Transformed from Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) Scores, and their Underlying Gene Frequencies

Not really. The reason why Americans tend to think Asians are smarter is that the Asians who come to America tend to be among the smarter and harder working people where the come from.Another factor is that Asians are, in fact, much harder working and more self disciplined than most Americans and, thus, tend to have higher levels of achievement. As Americans equate achievement more with intelligence than hard work they come to the conclusion that Asians are more intelligent but, in reality, its because they work harder.

Do you wonder why Chinese students who come to U.S are smart? Here is why:If one in 100 people can get into Harvard, then only one in 1000 people can get into the best university in China. 1 in 20 of these best students get to some good phd programs in U.S.  You have to be a really clever guy to beat the odds like this. I only speak for the Chinese.No, Chinese people are not clever. But U.S government is clever to get clever Chinese students here.

No. Some Asians are just trained early on to try to outsmart others. Our parents tell us we're dumb from an early age and that they expect smarter behaviour. They also push us to learn. They do this by using guilt and threats of beatings (when it was still legal here then). They yell a lot too. No matter how well you did end up doing, they would ask you after getting straight As how on earth did you end up with a B+ in maths? We are not smarter. We just overcompensate and are really insecure.

Studies have shown Chinese-speaking kids scored higher than English-speaking kids in basic arithmetic, but these experiments were around language and how easily the concepts of numbers were grasped.  In Chinese and English, the words for numbers 1 to 10 are unique and random and have to be learnt, but for Chinese number names from 11-19, they are based on systemic rules like "ten-one", "ten-two", "ten-three" etc.  In English, random names are given to "eleven" and "twelve" (tho there's some history behind it) and, for higher numbers, not all kids recognized that "teen" stands for "ten" and "thir" is "three". In even higher numbers,  "ten" becomes "-ty".  However, these studies also showed there was not a significant difference in overall learning of mathematics because it's also based on culture and context. As for how 'smart' one is, it depends on 1) what kind of smartness we are measuring eg. numbers-smart, book-smarts, street-smarts etc and 2) how accessible formal, institutional education is eg. big city, rural, immigrant, family life etc.  Im using specifically Ng and Rao's 2010 study "Chinese number words, culture and mathematical learning" and this article:http://m.psychologytoday.com/blog/freedom-learn/201312/language-measures-and-the-us-handicap-in-mat

I think it's hard to say if they're genetically smarter than others.  Their culture of having an intense work ethic can trump intelligence.  I  know a lot of uneducated Koreans who came to the USA penniless, and easily out earn many native born Americans through sheer hard work. Also, I personally don't believe in the validity of IQ tests.

The average IQ of asians is 105, which is a bit more than the average for all races. So asians - in general - have a slight advantage. But this doesn't say anything about individuals. If you are an asian with an IQ of 75 it would be stupid to brag about asians IQ. Well bragging about IQ is stupid no mather what your IQ is.

It’s more or less a stereotypes that Asians are smart, but there is a reason for that, and it’s most likely not genetics. You see, in East Asia, many cultures have Confucianism as part of their culture. What this means is that to Asians is that learning is one of the most important things in all of reality, and knowledge is power or will give you power, which is true. As such, Asians usually pressure their kids to do well in school to live successful lives. This academic pressure makes them give all their efforts into their School and Work, making the impression that we are smart.

The stereotype is that they are smarter, but I personally think that they are not really smarter! They may do well on tests in schools, but if you talk to one on the street, you wouldn't be able to tell!  So, WHY doesn't their intelligence show if they do so well on academic tests? Some may appear shy because they may be quieter since they may not speak English very well, but if you can't tell that they are smart outside of the classroom... then they're just not smart. The answer is very clear!  If you can't PROVE that you're smart, then you're not smart!!!!!!!!!!

i dont want to say race always equates to intellect because it might be racism. i used to love this game called earthbound on the nintendo series called mother in japan but i did notice that the asian character can only revive by eating “brain food” while the american character revives from junkfood. the uk themed character eats either and get by but can invent things so i would guess asia and europe generally make fun of the dumb white american stereotype on their own watch at times.

In general, people from other countries moving to the US will either be more apt to take advantage of our educational systems or pass the stringent qualifications needed to leave the country.   If you actually take a look at IQ's by country, many of these country have the same IQ as the United States.  This is one of a myriad of issues with using tests to measure aptitude. (DISCLAIMER: IQ is a Euro/Western construct which is a very narrow view of intelligence...)

While it is true that the average IQ as measured in IQ test varies strongly from country to country with some asian countries scoring highest up to 109 points and most western countries being some 5 points lower, the differences are IMHO certainly dominated by enviromental issues as IQ is sensitive to famine, illiterate, childhood infections, malaria, domestic violence and traumas. Each easily costing 5 points permanently on individials suffering on these accounts.

Depends on what you think makes someone smart. If you’re talking about IQ tests, then yes, most up to nearly all of their IQ averages surpass 100 up to 115 while everyone scores mostly below 100 (there is a diagram which shows this). If you’re talking about schools then yes again!! East Asians perform the best in maths and science in schools globally and are the most successful at getting high grades in maths and English gcse in the uk.

I suspect it's hybrids that are smarter, and more robust.  In WWII GIs married Asians and their offspring were all hybrids - carrying the genes of both sides of the family tree. In genetics it's a general rule that hybrid progeny are stronger than either parent - so I suspect this is true for humans.  Of course there are cultural differences, but I'm guessing that the success comes from the genetic hybrid background.

“Orientals” aka; Japanese, Chinese, Koreans, etc.. are shown to score top of most IQ tests regarding spatial awareness because of this these countries score highest in OECD math and sciences test. People need to acknowledge that ethnic groups share similar genetics and if common genes in that group is beneficial for intelligence then that group as a whole will have a higher intelligence. So to answer your question yes Oriental Asians are smarter than most other ethnic groups.
Perhaps not on all occasions, I think.

North Asian countries have a high average IQ, while, while Western hemisphere countries have large population of tropical people who have extremely low IQ levels. North Asians are a mix of Caucasian people and a now extinct, ancient Pacific island people. They may have appeared as late as the 1400s.
